title: Macbeth performances on Broadway pause after Daniel Craig tests positive for the coronavirus.
description: Daniel Craig, who is starring in the title role of a new Broadway production of Macbeth, tested positive for the coronavirus on Saturday, forcing the show to cancel most of next weeks performances.

title: North Carolina Wins the Battle of Tobacco Road, Retiring Krzyzewski
description: NEW ORLEANS  Hubert Davis put a photo of the Caesars Superdome, the site of this years mens Final Four, in the North Carolina locker room on the first day of practice this season.

title: The Next Battleground for College Basketball: How to Divide the Money
description: Update: South Carolina beat UConn to win its second national championship.

title: Quotation of the Day: Putin Reminds West He Has Economic Weapons as Well
description: The lesson for the West is that the effectiveness of financial sanctions can only go so far absent trade sanctions.

title: Corrections: April 3, 2022
description: A picture caption with an article on Page 4 about the many books returned after New Yorks public library systems ended late fees misstates the author and title of a work shown. It is Ninon de Lenclos by Emile Magne, not Magne by Ninon de Lenclos.

title: S.N.L. Spends a Night at the Oscars With Will Smith
description: In his opening monologue on Saturday Night Live, the host and comedian Jerrod Carmichael swore he wouldnt do it. Im not gonna talk about it, he said. He didnt even have to say what it was.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: SUNDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Toward the End of the Walk, a Bird Somewhere Ahead Burst Into Song
description: Dear Diary:

title: Why is the prime minister in trouble?
description: The critical blow for the leadership of Prime Minister Imran Khan of Pakistan came last year, when he appeared to lose the backing of the countrys powerful military.

title: Thomas Piketty Thinks America Is Primed for Wealth Redistribution
description: The French economist has hope for the country that, to a large extent, invented high, progressive taxation of income.

title: Young Mungo Explores Love and Violence in Emotional Technicolor
description: A critic could generate a whole book review simply by reproducing her marginalia. It would be boring to read but accurate, like an EKG printout. If the book in question were Young Mungo, by Douglas Stuart, it might begin with observations like Gorgeous writing! and Wow, before graduating to expletives and exclamation marks and wobbly underlines and question marks. Family-friendly adjectives do not always describe the yanking of certain heart strings in this lovely but occasionally overworked novel.

title: Abandoned, Trafficked, Living as a Man: A Chinese-American Coming of Age
description: FOUR TREASURES OF THE SKYBy Jenny Tinghui Zhang

title: Homes That Sold for Around $1.5 Million
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: Surrounded by War, Compassion Endures
description: More than 10 million Ukrainians have been displaced and more than 4 million have fled the country since Russia invaded Ukraine on Feb. 24. Cities and towns throughout the country continue to be bombarded by Russian artillery. Some are now nearly unrecognizable. Civilians have died, families have been ripped apart and lives have been forever changed.

title: A Canoeist Vanished. In Riverman, Ben McGrath Sets Out to Find Him.
description: Riverman opens with a mystery: a red canoe, found overturned and washed ashore in November 2014 on the swampy northern banks of Albemarle Sound in North Carolina, about 25 miles inland from Kitty Hawk. The boat is outfitted for a long haul, stuffed with bags containing electronics and reading matter and camping gear and annotated area maps, its lone paddle tethered securely to a gunwale. But ominously, there is no sign of any canoeist. Who was navigating this thing, and where to? And what has become of the missing boater?

title: Why Hundreds of New York City Prosecutors Are Leaving Their Jobs
description: New York Citys prosecutors are leaving in droves, citing pandemic burnout, low salaries and two intersecting laws that fundamentally changed the nature of their jobs.

title: The Latest Covid Misinformation Star Says He Invented the Vaccines
description: MADISON, Va.  I havent been able to ride a horse in months, Dr. Robert Malone said from his 50-acre horse farm about two hours southwest of Washington. Its just a constant barrage of requests for assistance.

title: Minnesota, a Mecca of Womens Basketball, Is Having Its Moment
description: Update: South Carolina beat UConn to win its second national championship.

title: In the Ocean, Its Snowing Microplastics
description: As long as there has been marine life, there has been marine snow  a ceaseless drizzle of death and waste sinking from the surface into the depths of the sea.

title: This Is True Barbarity: Life and Death Under Russian Occupation
description: TROSTYANETS, Ukraine  The last three Russian soldiers in this Ukrainian town are in the morgue, their uniforms bloodied and torn. The first ones face is frozen in pain. The second has his wooden pipe in his lap. The third is stuffed in his sleeping bag.

title: Who is Imran Khan?
description: Imran Khan was elected as Pakistans prime minister in 2018 when he ran as a nationalist promising to fight corruption, revive the countrys struggling economy and maintain an independent foreign policy that distanced Pakistan from the United States.

title: On Daylight Saving, There Are More Options Than You Might Think
description: The United States could soon be living with daylight saving time year-round if the Senate has its way.

title: The Sunday Read: They Came to Help Migrants. Now, Europe Has Turned on Them.
description: Exploring the personal experiences of Sara Mardini and Sen Binder, two volunteers who were arrested in February 2018 after helping migrants cross safely into Lesbos, Greece, the journalist Alex W. Palmer outlines the complex situation aid workers in Europe find themselves in: increasingly demonized by local authorities while also facing pressure from different ends of the international political spectrum.

title: We Will Fight for Every Brick of Ukraine
description: Since the beginning of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, thousands of buildings across the country have been destroyed by cruise missiles, aerial bombs and shells. Entire cities  Mariupol, Izium and Volnovakha  are almost demolished. In Kharkiv, some of the most important architectural monuments of the Soviet era and the prerevolutionary period have suffered extensive damage. A number of UNESCO World Heritage sites and architectural treasures are under threat.

title: Putin Had No Clue How Many of Us Would Be Watching
description: Almost six weeks into the war between Russia and Ukraine, Im beginning to wonder if this conflict isnt our first true world war  much more than World War I or World War II ever was. In this war, which I think of as World War Wired, virtually everyone on the planet can either observe the fighting at a granular level, participate in some way or be affected economically  no matter where they live.

title: Women, Do We Need an Intervention?
description: There have been a lot of jokes and memes about pandemic drinking by women, but the fact is that in the past two decades, women have often turned to alcohol more than they did in the past.

title: Taliban Outlaw Opium Poppy Cultivation in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban announced on Sunday that cultivating opium poppy in Afghanistan was banned, a move that will have far-reaching consequences for the many farmers who have turned to the illicit crop as a brutal drought and economic crisis have gripped the country.

title: This Week in Business: A Jobs Recovery
description: The March report continued the strong gains of recent months, with U.S. employers adding 431,000 jobs. The unemployment rate declined, and now, at 3.6 percent, it is just a touch higher than it was before the pandemic. The economy has recovered more than 90 percent of the 22 million jobs lost in the spring of 2020, far surpassing initial forecasts. Marchs showing may help tell a story about the changing attitudes toward the coronavirus, particularly as companies move ahead with return-to-office plans  the share of office workers doing their jobs remotely fell to 10 percent in March  and as tourism and in-person entertainment have largely resumed. The public may be moving toward the idea that the Covid era of the U.S. economy is done, one economist said.

title: For a Few Days at Augusta National, the Spotlight Shines on the Women
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.  Anna Davis had just turned 12 when Augusta National Golf Club, in a surprise, announced it would create a new national womens amateur championship. On Saturday, now 16 years old, Davis won the tournament.

title: Climate Optimism
description: Among the headline-grabbing wildfires, droughts and floods, it is easy to feel disheartened about climate change.

title: Whats Going On in This Picture? | April 4, 2022
description: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:

title: Economist Accused of Harassment Appears Set to Become Costa Ricas President
description: Rodrigo Chaves, a former World Bank official who has promised to shake up the political system of Central Americas most stable nation, was on track to become Costa Ricas new president, according to preliminary election results on Sunday night.

title: The documentarian Mantas Kvedaravicius is reported killed in Mariupol.
description: A Lithuanian documentary filmmaker has been killed in the besieged southern city of Mariupol, according to his colleagues and the Ukrainian Defense Ministrys information agency.

title: At Least 6 Dead and 12 Wounded in Mass Shooting in Sacramento, Police Say
description: SACRAMENTO  After more than two years of empty streets and withering commerce, Californias capital city seemed to be getting back to its pre-pandemic self this weekend. Thousands turned out for a concert at the downtown Golden 1 Center featuring Tyler, the Creator, and crowds filled the nearby bars, spilling into the spring night.

title: The Supreme Court hears a crucial case on Pakistans political crisis.
description: Hours after Prime Minister Imran Khan declared the National Assembly dissolved on Sunday, preventing a no-confidence vote that seemed sure to oust him, opposition leaders challenged the move before Pakistans Supreme Court.

title: Bill Fries, Singer Known for 1970s Trucking Ballad Convoy, Dies at 93
description: Bill Fries, the deep-voiced country singer known as C.W. McCall, who turned an ad campaign for an Iowa bread company into the outlaw trucker anthem, Convoy, which reached No. 1 on the charts in 1976 and inspired a Sam Peckinpah movie, died on Friday at his home in Ouray, Colo. He was 93.

title: Images of civilian victims in Ukraine spur some foreign volunteers to fight.
description: LVIV, Ukraine  Luis, a Mexican Army veteran, saw a photo of a wounded pregnant woman being carried out of a Ukrainian maternity hospital after a Russian airstrike and was reminded of his sister.

title: The Enemies of Liberalism Are Showing Us What It Really Means
description: After three decades of dominance, liberalism is losing its hold on Western minds, Matthew Rose writes in his powerful new book, A World After Liberalism.

title: Sri Lankas Cabinet Resigns as Street Protests Pressure Government
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  Sri Lankas cabinet resigned en masse on Sunday amid street protests and a dire economic crisis, the outgoing health minister said, leading to a vacuum in the leadership of a country largely controlled by its presidents powerful family.

title: Ahead of the Masters, Tiger Woods Hits the Driving Range and the Back Nine
description: Follow our live coverage of Tiger Woodss return to the Masters

title: Q. & A.: How to Fuel Your Runs
description: In high school, a teammate of mine would win every 400-meter race she entered with Dorito dust still on her fingertips. A college teammate traveled to races with a jar of peanut butter and a spoon. At the New York City Marathon a few years back, I watched a group of friends shotgun beers at the starting line.

title: A top China official signals a commitment to zero Covid as Shanghai battles an outbreak.
description: As Shanghai struggles to contain an Omicron outbreak, a top Chinese official vowed to adhere to a zero Covid policy to stamp out the virus in the shortest time possible.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Good morning. Every dish exists in its own continuum, Bryan Washington wrote in The New York Times Magazine this week, but they become interconnected through our personal experience. You eat a meal that blows your mind. That dish works its way into your life. One year, you go heavier on the garlic. The next, a little lighter on the char. Or maybe you grow to prefer more chile, more lime, more heat, until a meals history becomes interlocked with your own.

title: 7 Life-Affirming Habits That Readers Picked Up During the Pandemic
description: Last week, I asked readers to share practices, habits, or perspectives that they have picked up during the pandemic that theyd like to carry with them in the years ahead. The response was incredible; story after story of beauty and goodness discovered in these difficult years. I teared up reading them. I texted my husband: People are amazing.

title: Michelle Materre, Champion of Black Independent Film, Dies at 67
description: Michelle Materre, a distributor and educator who promoted Black womens voices in film and released influential independent movies by Black creators, died on March 11 in White Plains, N.Y. She was 67.

title: Estelle Harris, Georges Mother on Seinfeld, Dies at 93
description: Estelle Harris, who hyperventilated her way into the hearts of millions of Seinfeld fans as Georges mother, Estelle Costanza, died on Saturday in Palm Desert, Calif. She was 93.

title: U.S. and European leaders express outrage at the images from Bucha.
description: Western officials expressed outrage on Sunday at videos and images emerging from Bucha, a town near Kyiv, that appeared to show civilian bodies scattered on the streets after Russia withdrew its troops from the area in recent days.

title: The Value of Camps for Grieving Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Members of the Mighty Diamonds, Acclaimed Reggae Trio, Are Dead
description: Two members of the Mighty Diamonds, a Jamaican trio that helped lead the wave of roots reggae arising from the streets of Kingston to international acclaim in the 1970s, have died within days of each other.

title: Stream These 10 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
description: Oscar season is over (finally), but this months slate of movies leaving Netflix in the United States is full of winners and nominees past and present, as well as a handful of cult items and action epics. Toss these titles  nine movies and one favorite 90s TV show  into your list before theyre gone. (Dates reflect the final day a title is available.)

title: Review: Two Sopranos Make an Elektra Both Mythic and Human
description: Behind the glorious excess of Strausss Elektra  the librettos mythic setting, the scores unsparing terror  is something smaller: a starkly framed family portrait, albeit one knocked off the wall and scratched up by shards of shattered glass.

title: Opposition leaders accuse Pakistans prime minister of high treason.
description: Opposition leaders in Pakistan reacted with outrage to Prime Minister Imran Khans move to dissolve Parliament, accusing him of high treason and subverting the countrys constitutional order.

title: 2022 Grammys: See All the Stars on the Red Carpet
description: Before the album of the year, the fashion of the night.

title: Russia has committed apparent war crimes, Human Rights Watch says.
description: WARSAW  A leading human rights group said it had documented apparent war crimes by Russian forces against Ukrainian civilians in the occupied areas of the Chernihiv, Kharkiv and Kyiv regions in Ukraine.

title: After bottoming out early in the pandemic, U.S. car dealers profits are soaring.
description: The last time the National Automobile Dealers Association was able to hold its annual convention in person, the mood was far different. In a word, grimmer.

title: Review: The Balletic Rise and Fall of Eva Pern
description: Ballet Hispnico, founded in 1970, has been honoring its 50th anniversary for a solid two years. On Friday at the inaugural City Center Dance Festival, the company presented the final program in this extended celebration, which got off to a rocky start with canceled performances in April 2020. Anniversary events often feel like empty fanfare, but this turned out to be a milestone, a breakthrough: the companys first evening-length production, and a striking one at that.

title: Pakistans Prime Minister Dissolves Parliament, Blocking an Effort to Remove Him
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Prime Minister Imran Khan dissolved Pakistans National Assembly and called for new elections on Sunday, blocking a no-confidence vote that had been widely expected to remove him from office and plunging the country into a constitutional crisis.

title: Some U.S. states see new cases increase.
description: Across the United States, officials have dropped mask mandates and are closing mass vaccine and testing sites as new coronavirus cases have fallen nationally to about 27,000 a day on average. But several states  mostly in the Northeast  have had some increases in case numbers over the past two weeks, according to a New York Times database

title: Flurry of New Laws Move Blue and Red States Further Apart
description: SACRAMENTO  After the governor of Texas ordered state agencies to investigate parents for child abuse if they provide certain medical treatments to their transgender children, California lawmakers proposed a law making the state a refuge for transgender youths and their families.

title: Grammys 2022 Winners: The Complete List
description: The 64th annual Grammy Awards took place Sunday night after being delayed by the Omicron variant. The show was held in Las Vegas for the first time at the MGM Grand Garden Arena, and Trevor Noah returned as the host. A majority of the awards were presented at the premiere ceremony, held before the telecast.

title: California Law Requiring Board Diversity Is Struck Down
description: A California law requiring diversity on corporate boards of directors has been struck down in a blow to the states efforts to address racial and gender disparities in the workplace.

title: Fighting Was Easier: Taliban Take On a Treacherous, Avalanche-Prone Pass
description: THE SALANG PASS, Afghanistan  The Taliban commanders sneakers had soaked through from the melting snow, but that was the least of his problems. It was avalanche season in the Salang Pass, a rugged cut of switchback roads that gash through the Hindu Kush mountains in northern Afghanistan like some man-made insult to nature, and he was determined to keep the essential trade route open during his first season as its caretaker.

title: Covid and Diabetes, Colliding in a Public Health Train Wreck
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Herschel Walker, the Worst Candidate, Trump-Approved
description: Lets just be blunt. No one, and I mean not one person, would seriously believe that Herschel Walker, the former football star and current leading contender for the Republican Senate nomination in Georgia, was at the top of his class at the University of Georgia.

title: Your Monday Briefing: Reports of Russian Atrocities
description: As Russian forces retreat from Kyiv, they are leaving horror in their wake: Videos and images show the bodies of civilians lying in the streets. Ukrainian officials accused Russian forces of executing civilians.

title: A Red Cross convoy has still not reached Mariupol, the organization says.
description: An aid convoy that has been trying to reach Mariupol since Friday still has not made it to the besieged southern port city, the International Committee of the Red Cross said on Sunday.

title: U.S. nursing home deaths appear to be at pandemic lows.
description: Deaths at American nursing home residents from Covid appear to be at their lowest levels since the coronavirus first swept the United States more than two years ago, according to the most recent data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.

title: Thunder Lizard
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  First, lets congratulate Tyler Hinman, the winner of the grand prize at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, who has now won the tournament seven times. In addition, congratulations to Dan Feyer and David Plotkin, Mr. Hinmans opponents in the A Division. Finally, congratulations to Sid Sivakumar, the winner of the Wordle competition.

title: After Injury, Armando Bacot Isnt Deterred by Quick Turnaround
description: Follow our live coverage of North Carolina vs. Kansas in the NCAA Championship game.

title: In a Kyiv Suburb,They Shot Everyone They Saw
description: BUCHA, Ukraine  When a column of Russian tanks drove into the Kyiv suburb of Bucha in the first days of the war, Tetiana Pomazanko thought they held Ukrainian soldiers and went out to her front gate to see.

title: The Future of Tennis, Carlos Alcaraz, Has Arrived
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.  In a decade or so, after Carlos Alcaraz has piled up the Grand Slam tournament trophies, a four-week stretch in early 2022 may stand out as the time he took over tennis.

title: Pro-Putin Leaders in Hungary and Serbia Set to Win Re-election
description: BUDAPEST  Overshadowed by the war in Ukraine, elections on Sunday in Hungary and Serbia appear to have extended the tenures of Europes two most Kremlin-friendly leaders, both populist strongmen fortified by their overwhelming control of the media and cheap energy from Russia.

title: Trevor Noah returns as host, after a dust-up with Kanye West.
description: Trevor Noah, the comedian and face of The Daily Show, is returning to host the Grammy Awards for the second year in a row. For the 2021 show, Noah was front and center at an unconventional Grammys, with some performances pretaped and the bulk of the ceremony held outside the Staples Center (now known as the Crypto.com Arena) in Los Angeles. On the whole, Noah made something that could have felt like several competing shows feel like one, The New York Times pop music critic Jon Caramanica wrote.

title: Video Appears to Show Civilians Killed in Bucha
description: Ukrainian officials accused Russian forces of killing civilians in Bucha, Ukraine, a suburb northwest of Kyiv. Russian officials denied the allegations.

title: Leaky Black Has a Lot on His Mind, and Thats OK
description: Follow our live coverage of North Carolina vs. Kansas in the NCAA Championship game.

title: NASA Stops Launch Rehearsal for Its Giant Moon Rocket
description: NASA on Sunday morning cut short a practice countdown for its new megarocket, the Space Launch System. It is a key component of upcoming missions to return astronauts to the moon, and the agency said there was a problem with the mobile launch tower.

title: $4.8 Million Settlement Reached in Troopers Fatal Shooting of a Black Driver
description: The state of Georgia will pay a $4.8 million settlement to the family of a 60-year-old Black man who was fatally shot by a state trooper in 2020 during a traffic stop over a broken taillight, officials said.

title: Review: In Paradise Square, Racial Harmony Turns to Discord
description: Everything in Paradise Square is true. Nothing in Paradise Square is true.

title: Balkan Bordello Review: A Tragic Tale Reborn for a Time of War
description: To Orestes, the discord between his parents is part of the family dysfunction. Thats true as far as it goes, but it does gloss over some gruesome details: his military commander father, Agamemnon, sacrificing Orestess sister, Iphigenia; and his mother, Clytemnestra, avenging her favorite childs death by killing Agamemnon when he returns home from war.

title: Glass Animals miss ceremony after lead singer tests positive for Covid-19.
description: The lead singer of the British alternative-pop band Glass Animals  a nominee for best new artist  tested positive for the coronavirus, and all of its members have decided to not attend the awards show, the group said in an Instagram post on Sunday.

title: Silk Sonic wins song of the year.
description: The first televised award of the night, following three elaborate performances, was a major one: Leave the Door Open, by the throwback soul and R&B duo Silk Sonic, won song of the year, a category with 10 total nominees and steep competition. The track peaked at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart.

title: Billions Season 6, Episode 11 Recap: I Like Mike
description: Michael [expletive] Prince is running for president.

title: South Carolina, a Dominant Force All Season, Delivers a Championship Over UConn
description: MINNEAPOLIS  It was a 40-minute championship game, yes.

title: Volodymyr Zelensky speaks to Grammys audience in a prerecorded video.
description: Volodymyr Zelensky, the president of Ukraine, addressed the Grammy Awards in a video, giving an emotional plea for support in his countrys war against Russia.

title: The Grammys pays tribute to Taylor Hawkins, Stephen Sondheim and other music luminaries.
description: The Grammy Awards took an extended moment to honor Taylor Hawkins, the Foo Fighters drummer who died just over a week ago while on tour with the band in Colombia.

title: Word of the Day: deciduous
description: The word deciduous has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 8 in the book review Did the First Americans Arrive via Land Bridge? This Geneticist Says No. by Jeremy DeSilva:

title: With Each New Crisis in Hong Kong, Pressure Built on a Beijing Loyalist
description: HONG KONG  Under the watch of Carrie Lam, Hong Kongs chief executive, huge citywide protests deepened political divisions. A national security law silenced a once-vibrant civil society. And restrictive pandemic policies threatened Hong Kongs status as Asias world city.

title: Delayed by Virus, Grammy Awards Celebrate Music Industrys Return
description: The 64th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night featured major wins by Silk Sonic, Jon Batiste and Olivia Rodrigo, elaborate performances from a music industry struggling to emerge from the pandemic and an impassioned plea for help from President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.

title: Is UConns Dynasty Done? Auriemma Likes the Outlook for Next Year.
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Connecticut has spent almost three decades as the most formidable threat in womens college basketball, dangerous even when not ranked No. 1 in Division I for weeks at a time  which is where the Huskies spent a significant portion of that time.

title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Growing evidence of Russian atrocities against civilians in Ukraine has brought home the horrific toll of the war, prompting world leaders to threaten even harsher sanctions, including a lockout of Russias vital gas industry, a step some had been loath to take. Follow the latest updates from the war and maps of the invasion.

title: Whats on TV This Week: A Pair of New Docs, and Killing Eve
description: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: MONDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Still Going, Even as the Glory Fades
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  He started to believe in a curse. Then he trusted in a different kind of destiny. Baseball has a way of toying with emotions. Ask Mike Montgomery.

title: A Georgia Restaurant Has a Racist History. What Should Become of It?
description: SMYRNA, Ga.  For half a century, celebrities, tourists and local residents flocked to Aunt Fannys Cabin, a restaurant known as much for its Southern menu as for its depiction of plantation life and racist imagery, where white patrons were served by young Black waiters with yoke-like wooden menu boards hung around their necks.

title: A Challenger Emerges in the National League
description: In the San Francisco Giants and the Los Angeles Dodgers, the National League West had the two best teams in the majors during the 2021 regular season. But after winning the N.L. East (again), the scrappy Atlanta Braves knocked off the Dodgers in the National League Championship Series and then upset the Houston Astros in the World Series. While hoping for a repeat, Atlanta faces a daunting challenge in the form of Steven A. Cohens massive bank account, as the Mets owner seems determined to spend whatever it takes to get his childhood favorite team its first title since 1986.

title: American League Has an East Coast Bias
description: After the dust of the off-season settled, the American League had a huge shuffling of stars. But the power still resides largely in the stacked East, where four teams topped 90 wins last year. With Houston weakened by the loss of Carlos Correa and the teams in the West having various holes, the East could be even more dominant this season.

title: Rex Chapman Isnt Sure He Deserves Good Things
description: Sitting in a Midtown Manhattan cafe after shooting B-roll for his new show on CNN+, Rex Chapman says he knows that hes living a dream, and its making him uncomfortable. I struggle with it, he said.

title: Women Drive Off-Road in Saudi Desert for Fun and Bragging Rights
description: HAIL, Saudi Arabia  The starting line for the Rally Jameel was drawn in 2017, when women in Saudi Arabia earned the right to a drivers license. Last month, the ceremonial green flag finally fell on the kingdoms first all-women rally at Qishlah Palace in Hail, waved by Prince Abdulaziz bin Saad bin Abdulaziz, and Saudi Arabia marked another historic beginning for women.

title: French Election Opens Up as Marine Le Pen Surges
description: PARIS  At last, Emmanuel Macron stepped forth. The French president entered a vast arena this weekend, plunged into darkness and lit only by spotlights and glow sticks, before a crowd of 30,000 supporters in a domed stadium in the Paris suburbs.

title: Starbuckss new C.E.O. scraps stock buybacks to invest more profit into our people.
description: As Starbucks faces a rising wave of employee unrest, its new chief executive is abruptly shifting how the coffee chain splits its profits between workers and shareholders.

title: The Best Game That Money Could Buy
description: Money doesnt buy championships, but it certainly helps.

title: Quotation of the Day: Licensed to Drive, and Now Going Off-Road
description: My mother told me I am a daughter of the desert. Now I just want to drive rally as much as I can.

title: No Corrections: April 4, 2022
description: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.

title: Lesson of the Day: Asian Americans Grapple With Tide of Attacks
description: Featured Article: Asian Americans Grapple With Tide of Attacks: We Need Our Safety Back by Jeffery C. Mays, Dana Rubinstein and Grace Ashford

title: The Human Shields of the Abortion Rights Movement
description: BODIES ON THE LINE At the Front Lines of the Fight to Protect Abortion in AmericaBy Lauren Rankin

title: Covid Proved That the C.D.C. Is Broken. Michael Lewis Has Ideas for How to Fix It.
description: Dr. Anthony Fauci has been the face of Americas Covid response and has been praised and vilified for his expertise. But who are all the other people who have worked behind the scenes at agencies like the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to guide America through the pandemic? This is a question Michael Lewis tackles in his book The Premonition, which was published in May 2021. He talks about how getting to know these public health experts gave him a completely different understanding of the countrys public health system  and the systemic challenges institutions like the C.D.C. face when pandemics and other crises strike.

title: Im a Scientist in California. Heres What Worries Me Most About Drought.
description: Outside my lab near Donner Pass in the Sierra Nevada of California, new animal tracks are on the snow after a winter of hibernation, bird songs are lofting through the air, and the creek is flowing strongly with water from the melting snow. Spring has come worryingly early to the Sierra Nevada.

title: Ordinary People, Extraordinary Circumstances
description: To paraphrase Ian Fleming: To read one good book is happenstance; two is coincidence; three is wild good fortune. That a columnist should enjoy novels in her purview is not particularly noteworthy  but to read three excellent books in sequence, all for the same column, is unusual, a critics jackpot. These are stories of ordinary people in extraordinary circumstances, and the less you know about their plots going in, the better.

title: The End of the Covid Emergency Could Mean a Huge Loss of Health Insurance
description: If there has been a silver lining to this terrible Covid-19 pandemic, it is that the rate of Americans without health insurance dropped to a near historic low, thanks to various federal initiatives connected to the government-declared public health emergency.

title: The Problem of Personal Precedents of Supreme Court Justices
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: The Kids Are Right About Email, Too
description: NASHVILLE  My great-grandfather, whom the family called Papa Doc, was a country doctor who practiced medicine by examining sick people in their own homes and delivering babies in their parents own beds. For that reason, Papa Docs house, though modest even by Lower Alabama standards, was one of the first in the county to have a telephone.

title: New Era of Deals for College Players Means Business Considerations, Like Taxes
description: NEW ORLEANS  Trevor Keelss timing was impeccable. The Duke freshman scored 25 points in his first college game, a nationally televised triumph over Kentucky at the self-proclaimed mecca of college basketball, Madison Square Garden. He could not have picked a bigger stage  or a better time  to announce himself to the college basketball world.

title: A Private War: Why PTSD Is Still Overlooked
description: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

title: Its Clearly South Carolinas Time. Heres How Dawn Staley Crafted It.
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Dawn Staley was losing.

title: How the Recoil From Russian Gas Is Scrambling World Markets
description: Just months ago, Germanys plans to build a terminal for receiving shiploads of liquefied natural gas were in disarray. Would-be developers were not convinced customers would make enough use of a facility that can cost billions of dollars. And concerns about climate change undermined the future of a fossil fuel like natural gas.

title: A Flight Over China in Clear Skies, Followed by a Nosedive
description: BEIJING  China Eastern Airlines Flight 5735 was at 29,100 feet in clear afternoon skies over the hills of southern China, seemingly ready for a smooth landing in Guangzhou. The plane, a Boeing 737-800 NG, was only seven years old. One of Chinas most experienced aviators was among the three pilots in the cockpit.

title: Which Radioactive Republicans Are We Betting On?
description: Gail Collins: Bret, lets relax and talk about long-term goals that we totally do not share. For instance, how would you feel about raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour?

title: Shopping for Pot Racks
description: Whether youre short on cabinet space, or you like the look of a professional chefs kitchen or you just want to show off your cookware collection, pot racks and rails are the answer: They not only keep your skillets and saucepans handy, but they also double as decoration for the kitchen.

title: Gazing at the Black Sun: The Transfixing Beauty of Starling Murmurations
description: It was a late February evening in 2020, and I was standing in the marshlands of Friesland, a northern province in the Netherlands. Above my head, hundreds of thousands of starlings were swirling, swooping and diving in a dramatic fashion, blackening the sky.

title: Bristling Against the West, China Rallies Domestic Sympathy for Russia
description: While Russian troops have battered Ukraine, officials in China have been meeting behind closed doors to study a Communist Party-produced documentary that extols President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as a hero.

title: What Other Cities Can Teach New York About Homelessness on Transit
description: Days before New York Citys mayor unveiled a plan in February to address the issue of homeless people sheltering on the subway, three police officers in San Francisco were hustling a homeless woman up a staircase at the Civic Center transit station.

title: Jennifer Venditti Will See You Now
description: When Jennifer Venditti was a child growing up in Saint Paul, Minn., in the days before cellphones, her parents would sometimes deposit her with a babysitter for the night, leaving a contact number for where theyd be.

title: The Search for a Model Octopus That Wont Die After Laying Its Eggs
description: The tank looked empty, but turning over a shell revealed a hidden octopus no bigger than a Ping-Pong ball. She didnt move. Then all at once, she stretched her ruffled arms as her skin changed from pearly beige to a pattern of vivid bronze stripes.

title: The Prosecutors Who Are Heading For the Door
description: Good morning. Its Monday. Today well find out why prosecutors are leaving the New York City district attorneys offices in droves. Well also look at the techniques other cities are using to persuade homeless people to leave the subways.

title: How Much Do You Know About Bosnia and Herzegovina?
description: Can you find Bosnia and Herzegovina on a map? What else do you know about this Southeastern European nation with three million people?

title: Wall Streets Rigid Culture Bends to Demands for Flexibility at Work
description: When Tom Naratil arrived on Wall Street in the 1980s, work-life balance didnt really exist. For most bankers of his generation, working long hours while missing out on family time wasnt just necessary to get ahead, it was necessary to not be left behind.

title: The Illegality of the Plan Was Obvious
description: After months of investigation by a congressional committee, a federal judge has found that President Donald J. Trump and his allies most likely engaged in illegal activity in the wake of the 2020 election.

title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2022 Grammys
description: The 64th annual Grammy Awards promised a return to (relative) normalcy following a scaled-down 2021 ceremony that largely took place outdoors. In Las Vegas for the first time, and with the pop spectacle dialed back up, the shows most impactful moments were often its least flashy: a sober plea for help from President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine; Doja Cats teary moment at the microphone; performances on rooftops that put a spotlight on a different crop of artists. (High-octane live moments from Billie Eilish and H.E.R. made a big impact, too.) Here are the shows highlights and lowlights as we saw them.

title: Putins European allies
description: President Biden has described the world as being engaged in a battle between democracy and autocracy, and Ukraine has become the central front.

title: Senate negotiators announce a deal on a smaller Covid spending proposal without global vaccine funding.
description: Senators announced a deal on a $10 billion coronavirus aid package on Monday to provide additional aid for domestic testing, vaccination and treatment efforts, after dropping a push to include billions for the global vaccination effort.

title: The Biennial World Cup May Be Dead, but FIFAs Fight Isnt Over
description: DOHA, Qatar  Gianni Infantino strode into the bright lights of a packed convention center alongside the emir of Qatar on Friday and declared that he expected this years World Cup to be the best ever. It was not an unusual boast; Infantino has made it before, in Russia in 2018, and he will surely make it again when the tournament heads to North America in 2026. But behind his beaming smile, and his bombastic words, the trip to the desert had been the setting for the FIFA presidents latest disappointment.

title: Who Was Your Favorite Musical Artist This Year?
description: At the Grammy Awards on Sunday, Olivia Rodrigo, Silk Sonic and Jon Batiste took home some of the top prizes during what New York Times critic Jon Caramanica called an utterly inconsistent night.

title: Grammys Red Carpet: Show Girls, Tiger Queens and Pearly Kings
description: Ah, Las Vegas: It provides inspiration in so many ways. Thats how it seemed, anyway, judging from the Grammy red carpet, newly located to the MGM Grand Garden Arena in the city of  gosh, so many things! Sin and lights and camp and Elvis.

title: Elon Musk becomes Twitters largest shareholder.
description: Elon Musk has offered to buy Twitter, follow our live coverage of the news.

title: Zelensky blasts Merkel and Sarkozy for denying Ukraine NATO membership.
description: BRUSSELS  President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine lambasted the former leaders of Germany and France, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy, in a video address released late on Sunday, seemingly blaming them for the deaths of Ukrainian civilians.

title: Julian Gaines Has a Question: How Do I Paint Oregon Black?
description: In a cavernous studio on a weed farm in Forest Grove, Ore., about halfway between Portland and the Tillamook State Forest, Julian Gaines, an artist born and raised in Chicagoland, is creating a body of work devoted to Black American life.

title: What to Know About the Sacramento Shooting
description: Six people were killed and at least a dozen wounded in downtown Sacramento on Sunday in what the authorities say is the largest mass shooting in the citys history.

title: Carrie Lam, racked by Covid failures, wont seek a new term to lead Hong Kong.
description: HONG KONG  Carrie Lam, the chief executive of Hong Kong, announced on Monday that she would not seek a second term, after a huge surge in coronavirus infections left the global financial hub with one of the highest virus death rates in the world.

title: Elon Musks Latest Twitter Adventure
description: Elon Musk has offered to buy Twitter, follow our live coverage of the news.

title: What You Get for $3 Million in California
description: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a converted 1908 barn in Tiburon and a four-bedroom home in Geyserville.

title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: This house is in a mostly residential section of Altadena, about a five-minute drive from the shopping along Lake Avenue. A number of trailheads are within a short drive or walk, including Henninger Trailhead, which has paths of varying difficulty for hikers and mountain bikers.

title: At the Grammys, the Young Succeed Most When They Seem Old
description: There is no surer way for a young musician to acquire a quick coat of gravitas than an appearance on the Grammy Awards. And there is no surer way for a young musician to speed the way to the Grammys than by already appearing to be old.

title: You Want Your Child Vaccinated, but Your Ex Says No
description: In late 2021, Adele Grote, a divorced mother of two in Minneapolis, took her children to a vaccination clinic at the Mall of America. But when her 13-year-old daughter called her father to let him know they were getting the shot, Ms. Grote knew they would have to leave without it.

title: How to Avoid Sharing Misinformation on Ukraine
description: Uncritically sharing posts about Ukraine can make you an accidental conduit for war propaganda. Here's what to watch for.

title: She Moved From the Chem Lab to the Kitchen, but Not by Choice
description: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.

title: Downstate and Catch as Catch Can in Playwrights Horizons New Season
description: Downstate, a Bruce Norris play that The New York Timess chief theater critic, Jesse Green, has called a squirmy moral-thrill-ride, will make its New York premiere in October as part of Playwrights Horizonss new season, the company announced on Monday.

title: What to Cook Right Now
description: Good morning. We domestic sensualists live in a state of longing, no matter how comfortable our own places are, Laurie Colwin wrote in The Lone Pilgrim, and I often think about that when Im cooking. I could be, for instance, halfway through the preparation of Heston Blumenthals magical recipe for fried fish with vodka and beer batter (above) and realize, deep in my bones, that what I really desire is kimchi grilled cheese, or chicken paprikash.

title: 5 Takeaways From the U.N. Report on Limiting Global Warming
description: Nations are not doing nearly enough to prevent global warming from increasing to dangerous levels within the lifetimes of most people on Earth today, according to a new report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group of researchers convened by the United Nations. Limiting the devastation wont be easy, but it also isnt impossible if countries act now, the report says.

title: Stopping Climate Change Is Doable, but Time Is Short, U.N. Panel Warns
description: Nations need to move away much faster from fossil fuels to retain any hope of preventing a perilous future on an overheated planet, according to a major new report on climate change released on Monday, although they have made some progress because of the falling costs of clean energy.

title: Rwandan Court Declines to Extend Sentence for Paul Rusesabagina
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A court in Rwanda on Monday turned away an attempt by prosecutors to extend the 25-year sentence for Paul Rusesabagina, the hotelier turned dissident whose story was portrayed in the Oscar-nominated movie Hotel Rwanda, to life in prison.

title: Machine Gun Kelly Has a Second No. 1 Album, Mainstream Sellout
description: Machine Gun Kelly, the onetime rapper who has remade himself into the jester prince of a new wave of pop-punk, opens at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with his latest album, Mainstream Sellout.

title: Even a Broken Femur Cant Stop Tony Hawk
description: While everyones attention was focused elsewhere, another thing happened at this years Oscars. Tony Hawk, the worlds most iconic skateboarder, unveiled his latest trick: Standing without a cane.

title: New Mezcals With a Mad Backstory
description: A new mezcal, Fsforo, will add two spirits to the crowded mezcal market, with sales beginning online on Monday and on shelves April 18. Both are distilled from the tobal varietal of the agave plant, a species little known to Americans until recently and which has become increasingly popular among mezcal fans. Behind the spirits is Aarn Alva Snchez, a fourth-generation mezcalero (mezcal maker) in Huehuetln el Grande, Puebla, who has spent 20 years taming tobal, an agave plant with a reputation for being difficult to cultivate. In a twist, Fsforo is backed not by an actor or musician (as is common in the world of celebrity tequilas and mezcals), but by Jim Cramer of Mad Money fame and his wife, Lisa Detwiler. Fsforos two offerings are the fruity and grassy Tobal, and the ashy and vegetal Tobal Penca, which is aged for one to three months in glass carboys with a cooked agave leaf.

title: Understand the Science of Sourdough
description: Two years into the pandemic, and perhaps you still havent tackled sourdough? This highly detailed new book, Sourdough by Science, written with lively insight by Karyn Lynn Newman, a molecular biologist, might get you into fermentation after all. Dr. Newman clearly explains what goes on with sourdough starter. Though she gives instructions for developing your own, she recommends buying it for reliability. Different flours, salt, proportions and equipment, as well as the steps that ensure successful dough-making, are covered. And there are recipes, including options you might not associate with sourdough, like focaccia. What if your crust is not shiny? Is the flavor too sour? She troubleshoots as well.

title: A New Option for Kosher Meat Delivered to Your Door
description: Prairie Street Prime is a new delivery option for glatt kosher meat, like a hefty slab of brisket to braise for Passover (the first night is April 15), or for rib roast or tomahawk steak for a more spectacular presentation.  The company, based in Great Neck, N.Y, has been in development for several years. After some trial runs last year, it began shipping nationally this year. Some of the Star-K certified beef is U.S.D.A. Prime grade. The companys founder, Elliot Moskowitz, a financier, saw that for kosher meat there was no equivalent to high-end companies like Snake River Farms or Pat LaFrieda selling directly to consumers. So he stepped in. The prime tomahawk steak ($130), once seared, then finished in a slow oven, was quite tender and had rich flavor. At around 40 ounces, it serves two to four. The choice grade tomahawk is $100. There are also short ribs, rib steaks and roasts, prime or choice, as well as lamb and veal. The meats are shipped frozen.

title: Barachou Expands Its Offerings
description: Barachou, Rebecca Tisons Upper West Side pastry shop, opened in 2019 and specializes in a kaleidoscope of cream puffs and other French pastries. She found a steady clientele, which allowed her to open a second location. Its in the West Village and seems to attract a stream of shoppers and snackers for coffee and pastries at cafe tables. She has more kitchen space downtown and has expanded her repertory to include individual pastries and tarts, with more savory options like croissants and olive and Cheddar bread. More complex pastries, like Paris-Brest, and a thick French custard flan are also new.

title: A Tennessee Twist on Ham for Easter Brunch
description: Porter Road, a chef-owned butcher shop in Nashville that ships nationally, has assembled an Easter brunch package of ham and biscuits. (Just add eggs.) A half boneless ham  about 5.5 pounds of pasture-raised pork, cured, mildly smoked and ready for a slick of glaze for that Sunday centerpiece  will serve eight to 10. It comes with biscuits, both buttermilk and sharp Cheddar, and a tub of traditional Southern pimento cheese, all from Callies Hot Little Biscuit; $130, including shipping ($20 extra to some destinations). The company also sells half and whole hams without the accessories. Orders must be placed no later than April 11 for delivery by April 15.

title: Mother of Slain 12-Year-Old Begs for Answers: Im Asking for Justice
description: The family of a 12-year-old boy who was fatally shot last week in Brooklyn pleaded for answers at a news conference with Mayor Eric Adams on Monday, describing deep pain and frustration that innocent victims continue to be caught up in gunfire.

title: These Colorful Chocolate Easter Eggs Dazzle
description: Chocolate Easter eggs, half-eggs really, are having their Jackson Pollock moment this year at Norman Love Confections in Fort Myers, Fla. Mr. Love covers the dark, milk and white chocolate shells in ombr pastels with contrasting spatters. Inside are opulent fillings like caramel, coconut cream, coffee cream, peanut butter, raspberry and mango for a two-bite treat. There are 10 varieties, $26 for the box. An assortment of the  eggs and other chocolates, 25 pieces, is $55.

title: Ford and Stellantis say car sales fell at the start of the year.
description: Ford Motor said on Monday that its new-vehicle sales in the United States fell 17 percent in the first three months of the year, in line with other automakers that are struggling to keep their factories running amid a global shortage of computer chips.

title: Four Days That Changed Golf
description: Follow our live coverage of the first round of the Masters

title: Heres how Russia has avoided defaulting on its debt.
description: Despite strict economic sanctions, shrinking currency reserves and nervous banks, Russia has kept up with payments for government debt, confounding expectations from just a few weeks ago, when the ratings agencies believed a default was imminent and the government said it might repay its international loans in rubles.

title: Perfecting Neapolitan Pizza in Los Angeles, With Help From Tokyo
description: LOS ANGELES  Every day, the pizza at Pizzeria Sei is a tiny bit different from the day before. I know this because I cant stop going to Pizzeria Sei.

title: Horrified by the Killing of Civilians in Ukraine
description: To the Editor:

title: Cole Sprouse on Finding a Healthy Balance in Hollywood
description: I hope you dont mind, Im going to be scarfing down this chicken wrap at the same time we talk, Cole Sprouse politely informs me as he sits in the kitchen wearing a fuzzy, baby blue sweater. The wrap in question is already halfway to his mouth.

title: ICE Lawyers Directed to Clear Low-Priority Immigration Cases
description: WASHINGTON  The Biden administration is seeking to clear potentially hundreds of thousands of deportation and asylum cases pending before immigration courts, an unprecedented move that could significantly reduce the current backlog of 1.7 million cases.

title: Whats the Best Advice Youve Received About Motherhood?
description: Mothers can get lots of unsolicited advice, starting even before a child is born: Dont eat that, you might harm the baby! Sleep on your side, you dont want to cramp the little one! And once the kid arrives, all bets are off. From feeding an infant to disciplining an unruly teen, people seem to thinkits all up for discussion.

title: A Landscaper, an Aspiring Social Worker: Lives Cut Short in Sacramento Shooting
description: SACRAMENTO  The six people killed in an eruption of gunfire in downtown Sacramento over the weekend, one of the worst mass killings in the citys history, ranged in age from 21 to 57, the county coroners office said Monday.

title: Holy Cross is renaming its science complex for Fauci.
description: The College of the Holy Cross is renaming the science buildings on its campus in Worcester, Mass., in honor of one of its most famous graduates, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci.

title: Biden Calls Putin a War Criminal After Images from Bucha Surface
description: President Biden said reports of indiscriminate killings of civilians in the town of Bucha, Ukraine, constituted a war crime and that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia should face charges.

title: Jury Selection Begins in Sentencing Trial for Parkland Gunman
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.  In the four years since a former student killed 17 people and injured 17 others in Parkland, Fla., the classroom building where the shooting took place has remained standing, unused and fenced off, on the grounds of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.

title: A Century of the BBC, a Quasi-Mystical Part of Englands Psyche
description: The British Broadcasting Corporation, the BBC  the Beeb  turns 100 this year. Hullo, hullo, 2LO calling, 2LO calling, a few thousand listeners heard through the hissing ether at 6 p.m. on Nov. 14, 1922. This is the British Broadcasting Company. 2LO. Stand by for one minute please! What followed were short news and weather bulletins, read twice, the second time slowly so that listeners could take notes.

title: World War II, Ukraine and the Future of Conflict
description: Books have their own fates, the Romans taught. Running for just under a thousand small-print pages, Blood and Ruins, too, has had its own fate. After 40 years of painstaking scholarly effort, Richard Overy was overridden by Vladimir Putin. Russias murderous assault on Ukraine makes the subtitle, The Last Imperial War, 1931-1945, ring premature. After 77 years of relative peace in Europe, the longest ever, conquest and slaughter are back. So are sorrow and pity.

title: Atrocities in Bucha could complicate Russia-Ukraine talks.
description: Russian and Ukrainian negotiators have been holding intermittent peace talks since a few days after the war began, but it has not been clear that they would amount to anything  or that the Kremlin was serious about negotiating.

title: Why the Grammys Couldnt Resist Jon Batiste
description: Accepting the Grammy for album of the year on Sunday night, Jon Batiste delivered a minute-and-a-half manifesto that hinted at his roots in the musical culture of New Orleans.

title: Anne Parsons, Who Revived the Detroit Symphony, Dies at 64
description: Anne Parsons, who as president and chief executive revitalized the Detroit Symphony Orchestra in the aftermath of a bitter strike, using education and technology to attract new audiences, died on March 28 in Detroit. She was 64.

title: Book Banning Efforts Surged in 2021. These Titles Were the Most Targeted.
description: Attempts to ban books in the United States surged in 2021 to the highest level since the American Library Association began tracking book challenges 20 years ago, the organization said Monday.

title: With a Neutral Stance on Ukraine, Viktor Orban Pulled in Voters
description: BUDAPEST  Savoring the election victory of a rare European leader who has not condemned him as a war criminal, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday congratulated Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary for winning a fourth term and said he looked forward to an expansion of partnership ties.

title: The Ruble Has Bounced Back. What Does That Mean?
description: President Biden bragged on Twitter on March 26 that as a result of our unprecedented sanctions, the ruble was almost immediately reduced to rubble. It was an ill-timed tweet. The Russian currency did crash in February after sanctions were imposed, but by the time Biden exulted, it had already regained lost ground. Its now worth about 1.2 cents, which is down from 1.3 cents before the war but well above its wartime low of less than 0.8 cents.

title: Your Wife Seems to Care About the Rose Bushes
description: In the seven months since I began this newsletter, Ive received thousands of emails from readers. These have led to some in-depth correspondences with all sorts of people who have pushed my thinking in meaningful ways. Today I want to thank everyone who has written in and respond to some emails publicly, which Ill try to do somewhat regularly. I have always envisioned this newsletter as a dialogue between you and me, so if you have any concerns or thoughts or even just endless praise, please write to me at kang-newsletter@nytimes.com.

title: On the Scene: At a Far Right Rally in France
description: I went to a rally held by Marine Le Pen, the far-right French presidential candidate who is rising in the polls.

title: Supreme Court Rules Against Police in Malicious Prosecution Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Supreme Court ruled on Monday in favor of a Brooklyn man who said he had been falsely accused by police officers of resisting arrest, saying he could sue for malicious prosecution under a federal civil rights law.

title: Sri Lanka Protesters Defy President, Rejecting a Cabinet Shuffle
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  After weeks of upheaval over Sri Lankas economic crisis and growing resentment to his rule, President Gotabaya Rajapaksa offered the public a sacrifice, urging almost his entire cabinet, including several family members, to resign en masse while promising reform.

title: Satellite images show bodies lay in Bucha for weeks, despite Russian claims.
description: Update: New video shows Russian soldiers opening fire on a cyclist in Bucha.

title: U.S. colleges that once championed surveillance virus testing are backing away.
description: Colleges and universities across the United States have relaxed campus requirements for coronavirus testing of vaccinated people in recent weeks, chipping away at some of the last widespread surveillance testing programs and dismaying public health experts, who say that robust sources of transmission data will be lost.

title: Two More Republicans Back Jackson as Senate Moves Toward Confirmation
description: WASHINGTON  A nearly unified wall of G.O.P. opposition to Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson cracked slightly on Monday as two more Senate Republicans said they would side with Democrats in supporting her, paving the way for her confirmation as the first Black woman on the Supreme Court.

title: Gene Shue, All-Star and Longtime N.B.A. Coach, Dies at 90
description: Gene Shue, an All-Star N.B.A. guard of the late 1950s and early 60s who went on to turn losers into winners in 22 seasons as a pro coach, died Sunday at his home in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 90.

title: The Cocktail Bar Dead Rabbit Will Expand to New Orleans and Beyond
description: The Dead Rabbit is multiplying. The cocktail bar and pub in Lower Manhattan has plans to open new branches in New Orleans and Austin, Texas, in 2023, with hopes to open other locations in the next five years. A sister bar, called Hazel and Apple, will open in Charleston, S.C., later this year.

title: Dating Coach Charged in Capitol Riot Gets Prison Term for Gun Crime
description: A self styled dating coach who prosecutors say participated in the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol was sentenced to three and a half years in prison after he pleaded guilty to a gun possession charge in Manhattan Supreme Court on Monday  a case that emerged through a search warrant related to his apparent involvement in the riot.

title: The War Moves East, as Putin Looks for a Victory
description: KHARKIV, Ukraine  Soldiers waved off traffic, emerging from trenches dug into the side of a multistory apartment building, telling motorists to turn around. Firefighters arrived soon after, unfurling hoses to combat a growing blaze ignited by an artillery round that hit a nearby housing complex.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing: The Fallout from Bucha
description: President Biden called the indiscriminate civilian deaths in Bucha a war crime and said the U.S. would impose additional sanctions on Russia. Some European leaders also demanded tougher sanctions, including a total ban on Russian fuel imports. Here are the latest updates.

title: The Horror in Bucha
description: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

title: South Africa lifts its Covid state of disaster after two years.
description: JOHANNESBURG  South Africa is ending its national state of disaster over the coronavirus pandemic, which has been in effect for 750 days and allowed the government to impose some of the broadest public health restrictions seen anywhere.

title: Gov. Larry Hogan Approves New Maryland Congressional Map
description: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland on Monday signed into law a new congressional map drawn by Democrats, a little more than a week after a judge called their previous effort an extreme gerrymander and threw it out.

title: Judge Keeps New Yorks New Electoral Map Intact for Now
description: A New York appellate judge on Monday hit the brakes on a sweeping lower-court decision that invalidated newly drawn legislative districts favorable to Democrats and threatened to throw the states election season into turmoil.

title: Terry Francona Is Back and Feeling Feisty
description: GOODYEAR, Ariz.  Terry Francona is healthy again. You can see it in Mike Barnetts hair.

title: Images of Russian Atrocities Push West Toward Tougher Sanctions
description: The images of dead Ukrainians, some with their hands tied and others haphazardly buried in pits, spurred shocked Western leaders on Monday to promise even tougher sanctions against Russia, including possibly on energy, as the Kremlin dug in and showed signs of preparing a new assault.

title: Tommy Davis, Batting Star With the 60s Dodgers, Dies at 83
description: Tommy Davis, a former Brooklyn-born baseball prodigy who became a two-time All-Star, won two consecutive National League batting titles and led the star-studded Los Angeles Dodgers to a World Series championship in 1963, died on Sunday in Phoenix. He was 83.

title: Has the Pandemic Changed Your Mental Health?
description: After more than two years of illness, upheaval and loss, many of us are being asked to return to something resembling our prepandemic lives. Offices are filling up, masks are coming off and more governments and organizations are making plans to live with the virus.

title: Sitting at Home and Trembling: A Town Emerges After a Russian Retreat
description: NOVA BASAN, Ukraine  Badly frightened and hungry, residents of Nova Basan, a town east of Kyiv, emerged from their cottages and farmhouses on Monday, and described living through the terrifying ordeal of the Russian occupation  detentions, threats and a strict curfew that confined them to their homes with no outside communication for more than a month.

title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Senate Committee Votes on Jackson Nomination
description: Senators on the Judiciary Committee deadlocked 11 to 11 along party lines in the evenly divided chamber, forcing Democrats to take extra steps in the full Senate to keep Ketanji Brown Jacksons confirmation to the Supreme Court on track.

title: Covids Toll on Diabetic Americans
description: After older people and nursing home residents, no other group seems to have been hit harder by Covid than people with diabetes. They account for a staggering 30 to 40 percent of all U.S. Covid deaths, several studies suggest.

title: U.S. government to jury in 1MDB trial: Convict even if you dont believe our star witness.
description: A federal prosecutor told jurors on Monday that they had received enough evidence to convict a former Goldman Sachs banker for his role in one of the biggest international money laundering and bribery schemes even without the testimony of the governments star witness.

title: Lygia Fagundes Telles, Popular Brazilian Novelist, Dies at 98
description: Lygia Fagundes Telles, one of Brazils most popular writers, whose stories of women trapped in unsatisfying relationships could also be read as allegories of her countrys political situation, died on Sunday at her home in So Paulo. She was 98.

title: Western Officials Condemn Reports of Massacre by Military in Central Mali
description: DAKAR, Senegal  French, American and European officials have expressed serious concerns about allegations that hundreds of people were killed last week in a town in the West African nation of Mali by Malian soldiers accompanied by Russian mercenaries on a campaign to fight insurgents.

title: TikTok to the Grammys: How a Bridgerton Musical Beat Broadway
description: When the lyricist-composer duo behind The Unofficial Bridgerton Musical stepped onstage Sunday to accept their Grammy for best musical theater album, the list of people they wanted to thank did not start with a record label or producer, but with their social media followers.

title: Medicare enrollees can get free home coronavirus tests from pharmacies.
description: Roughly 60 million Americans who are enrolled in Medicare can now get up to eight free home coronavirus tests per month from pharmacies or health care providers in a move by the Biden administration to expand testing access.

title: Sarah Palin Knows How to Get Attention. Can She Actually Win?
description: The last time Sarah Palin and Donald Trump shared a stage together, the former Alaska governor gave a meandering endorsement speech that displayed her inventiveness with the English language  and her instinctive connection to the Republican base.

title: A Small Earthquake on Staten Island
description: I grew up in a relatively equal society, at least as far as incomes were concerned. Obviously there were class differences in 1974, the year I graduated from college; some jobs paid much better than others, some people were rich while others were desperately poor. But for most Americans these differences were much narrower than they are today.

title: Bidens Will Host a White House Wedding Reception for Their Granddaughter
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden and Jill Biden, the first lady, plan to host a wedding reception this fall at the White House for their eldest granddaughter, Naomi Biden, who is set to marry her longtime boyfriend.

title: Why Are Seemingly Functional Adults Falling for the Furries Myth?
description: A Nebraska state senator, Bruce Bostelman, last month warned of an alarming new variety of deviance making its way into the states schools. Its something called furries, he said. Schoolchildren, Bostelman claimed, were identifying as cats or dogs. They meow and they bark. And educators, indulging them, are wanting to put litter boxes in the schools for the children to use, said Bostelman.

title: The matchup between the big men will be one to watch.
description: In a basketball world where elite guard play and sharpshooting is both cherished and prioritized, the outcome of this national championship game could be decided by the towering, physical players who make the most impact around the rim.

title: The C.D.C. will undergo a comprehensive re-evaluation, the agencys director said.
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention will undergo a monthlong comprehensive review and evaluation, a first step in modernizing its systems and processes and transforming it for the future, Dr. Rochelle Walensky, the agencys director, announced on Monday.

title: Important Markings on Treasure Maps
description: TUESDAY PUZZLE  The American Crossword Puzzle Tournament ran April 1 to 3, and I hope that those who attended had a fabulous time. Congratulations to everyone who competed. You can read more about the tournament in Alexis Benvenistes tour of the A.C.P.T.

title: Review: In Take Me Out, Whose Team Are You On?
description: Not for nothing is Darren Lemming, the fictional center fielder of a team called the Empires, also at the center of Take Me Out, Richard Greenbergs gay fantasia on the national pastime.

title: Kansas, With the Magic of a Record Comeback, Snatches Title Over North Carolina
description: NEW ORLEANS  As Kansas players glumly trudged off the Superdome floor at halftime on Monday night, down by 15 points, mired in foul trouble and dazed by a powder blue North Carolina hurricane, David McCormack was all smiles.

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Images of dead Ukrainians in the Kyiv suburb of Bucha, some with their hands tied and others haphazardly buried in pits, spurred shocked Western leaders yesterday to promise even tougher sanctions against Russia, including possibly on energy. The Kremlin dug in and showed signs of preparing a new assault. Follow the latest updates.

title: Corrections: April 5, 2022
description: An article on Sunday about the Minverva Virgo, a tanker loaded with Russian oil that was forced to change course after its buyer fell through, misstated the tankers country of registry. The ship is Greek-flagged, not Croatian-flagged.

title: In a Battle of Bigs, Kansas David McCormack Delivers
description: NEW ORLEANS  David McCormack and his Kansas teammates were trailing by 15 points at halftime of the national championship game, but he was smiling just the same.

title: Jimmy Kimmel Mocks Trumps Endorsement of Sarah Palin
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Woman Is Fatally Shot in Bronx Crossfire
description: A 61-year-old woman was fatally shot on Monday night in the Bronx, caught in the crossfire after two groups of men began arguing nearby with guns drawn, the police said.

title: Remy Martin Gets Finish Kansas Wanted After Rocky Season
description: NEW ORLEANS  After the final buzzer, as he made his way across the court, the Kansas transfer guard Remy Martin stared triumphantly at the Jayhawks fans who were pressing against the Superdomes railings to get as close as they could to him.

title: Word of the Day: decrepit
description: The word decrepit has appeared in 83 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Oct. 10 in A Street Basketball Mecca Gets a Face-Lift by Jonathan Abrams:

title: Forgiveness
description: A recent Times Opinion piece reflects on the meaning of Lent, a season in preparation for Easter when Christians often focus on sin and repentance.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: TUESDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.

title: Do Home Covid Tests Expire?
description: Q: Do home Covid tests really expire? I ordered what I was allowed. Now I see they have expiration dates. Some have already expired. What to do? Keep and use, or throw them out?

title: Learning the Right Way to Struggle
description: When Hunter, 6, started first grade last autumn, he struggled to match letter sounds with the shape of letters on paper. He found writing letters hard and writing words even harder. It felt bad, he said recently.

title: Up-Close Ukraine Atrocity Photographs Touch a Global Nerve
description: Perhaps it was the way the lifeless bodies, bloodied by bullets, and some with hands bound, had been left strewn about or shoveled into makeshift mass graves. Or the reality of seeing them up close in widely circulated photographs and videos.

title: Lesson of the Day: We Know the Pledge. Its Author, Maybe Not.
description: Featured Article: We Know the Pledge. Its Author, Maybe Not.  by Sam Roberts

title: 200,000 Dead, One Lone Defendant as Darfur Trial Begins
description: They were known as the janjaweed, the armed militia men who came racing on camels and horses at dawn, moving fast to kill and rape, burning huts and leaving another village destroyed in the Darfur region of Sudans impoverished far west.

title: With Bittersweet, Can Susan Cain Replicate the Success of Quiet?
description: BITTERSWEETHow Sorrow and Longing Make Us WholeBy Susan Cain

title: Love and Scandal, Buried for Years at an Elite Boarding School
description: SCHOOL DAYSBy Jonathan Galassi

title: Memphis Is a Rhapsodic Hymn to Black Women
description: MEMPHISBy Tara M. Stringfellow

title: When an Advice Columnist Tries to Fix Her Daughters Issues
description: THE WISE WOMENBy Gina Sorell

title: Is It Possible to Body-Block Our Loved Ones From Pain? Alas, No.
description: BOMB SHELTERLove, Time and Other ExplosivesBy Mary Laura Philpott

title: How Far Will Parents Go to Protect Their Sons?
description: THE LIFEGUARDSBy Amanda Eyre Ward

title: In Atomic Anna, the Nuclear Disaster in Chernobyl Launches a Time-Traveling Adventure
description: ATOMIC ANNABy Rachel Barenbaum

title: Sex Goddess, Celebrity and the Best Hope for Her Country
description: I WAS THE PRESIDENTS MISTRESS!!By Miguel Syjuco

title: A Son Looks Back on Life With an Irascible and Beloved Mother
description: TASHAA Sons MemoirBy Brian Morton

title: How to Record Thunderstorms
description: You have to be patient because you cant control thunderstorms, says Frank Bry, 59, a sound effects recordist who creates libraries of sounds that he sells to video-game, television, movie and white-noise production companies. Bry has four collections of thunderstorm recordings collected over 30 years from his home in rural northern Idaho. Know that the landscape around you will shape how thunder sounds. Bry lives near a large lake surrounded by mountain ranges, resulting in a volume and resonance he calls bodacious. Still, he covets the way thunder peals over the deserts of New Mexico. Ive heard pretty phenomenal thunder recordings from there, Bry says. The sound is crisp and dry.

title: The Magic of Tiny-Home Videos
description: I wouldnt mind living in a bathroom if it was the one at Jessica Albas family home, which has more windows (five) and shower heads (two) than my airless apartment in Queens. And Rainn Wilsons pet pigs, who sleep in their own casita with a Dutch door  aptly called the Pig Palace  have already realized my pastoral fantasy and desire for more breathing space.

title: I Didnt Feel Like Going, but Im Glad I Did: My Motto of the Moment
description: One recent snowy Saturday morning, I coaxed myself out of bed, into semiformal attire and through the door to synagogue. It was the latest in a series of attempts to force myself to, well, do stuff, the kind of stuff that takes me out of my one-bedroom apartment and into human society.

title: Can I Utter a Racial Slur in My Classroom?
description: I teach business law at a private university. One undergraduate course I teach is employment law, which covers discrimination under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964. I believe it is important to explain the groundbreaking significance of this legislation to my students, so I delve into the de facto apartheid in the South, with its Jim Crow laws, the widespread discrimination against all types of minority groups and the resistance by many legislators, especially in the South, to the passage of this law.

title: Lessons Learned From Michele McNally
description: Michele McNally, who served as The New York Timess director of photography and then as a top newsroom manager, died on Feb. 18 at age 66. When she started at the newspaper in 2004, her mission was clear: to enhance The Timess photojournalism and to show the newsroom just how powerful visual storytelling could be. She achieved both. Under her leadership, The Times won six Pulitzer Prizes for photography. But she also left a mark on the lives of those she worked with. Here, two Times photographers, Josh Haner and Joo Silva, share how Ms. McNally shaped The Times and their careers.

title: Shanghai Avoided Covid Disaster for Two Years. Now Were Locked Down.
description: SHANGHAI  The volunteers in full protective gear  called big whites here in China  have packed up and moved on for the day; the apartment complex where I live is once again sequestered in silence.
